column2: The chief importance of knowledge by description is that it enables us to pass beyond the limits of our private experience.
column3: The chief importance of knowledge by description is that it enables us to pass beyond the limits of our private experience.

column2: In spite of the fact that we can only know truths which are wholly composed of terms which we have experienced in acquaintance, we can yet have knowledge by description of things which we have never experienced.
column3: In spite of the fact that we can only know truths which are wholly composed of terms which we have experienced in acquaintance, we can yet have knowledge by description of things which we have never experienced.

column2: In almost all our previous discussions we have been concerned in the attempt to get clear as to our data in the way of knowledge of existence.

column2: What things are there in the universe whose existence is known to us owing to our being acquainted with them?
column3: What things are there in the universe whose existence is known to us owing to our being acquainted with them?

column2: So far, our answer has been that we are acquainted with our sense-data, and, probably, with ourselves.
column3: So far, our answer has been that we are acquainted with our sense data, and, probably, with ourselves.

column2: These we know to exist.
column3: These we know to exist.

column2: And past sense-data which are remembered are known to have existed in the past.

column2: This knowledge supplies our data.

column2: But if we are to be able to draw inferences from these data--if we are to know of the existence of matter, of other people, of the past before our individual memory begins, or of the future, we must know general principles of some kind by means of which such inferences can be drawn. It must be known to us that the existence of some one sort of thing, A, is a sign of the existence of some other sort of thing, B, either at the same time as A or at some earlier or later time, as, for example, thunder is a sign of the earlier existence of lightning.
column3: But if we are to be able to draw inferences from these data-if we are to know of the existence of matter, of other people, of the past before our individual memory begins, or of the future, we must know general principles of some kind by means of which such inferences can be drawn. column3: If this were not known to us, we could never extend our knowledge beyond the sphere of our private experience; and this sphere, as we have seen, is exceedingly limited.

column2: The question we have now to consider is whether such an extension is possible, and if so, how it is effected.
column3: The question we have now to consider is whether such an extension is possible, and if so, how it is effected.

column2: Let us take as an illustration a matter about which none of us, in fact, feel the slightest doubt.
column3: Let us take as an illustration a matter about which none of us, in fact, feel the slightest doubt.

column2: We are all convinced that the sun will rise to-morrow.
column3: We are all convinced that the sun will rise to morrow.

column2: Why?
column3: Why?

column2: Is this belief a mere blind outcome of past experience, or can it be justified as a reasonable belief?
column3: Is this belief a mere blind outcome of past experience, or can it be justified as a reasonable belief?

column2: It is not easy to find a test by which to judge whether a belief of this kind is reasonable or not, but we can at least ascertain what sort of general beliefs would suffice, if true, to justify the judgement that the sun will rise to-morrow, and the many other similar judgements upon which our actions are based.
column3: It is not easy to find a test by which to judge whether a belief of this kind is reasonable or not, but we can at least ascertain what sort of general beliefs would suffice, if true, to justify the judgement that the sun will rise to morrow, and the many other similar judgements upon which our actions are based.

column2: It is obvious that if we are asked why we believe that the sun will rise to-morrow, we shall naturally answer 'Because it always has risen every day'.
column3: It is obvious that if we are asked why we believe that the sun will rise to morrow, we shall naturally answer 'Because it always has risen every day'.

column2: We have a firm belief that it will rise in the future, because it has risen in the past.
column3: We have a firm belief that it will rise in the future, because it has risen in the past.

column2: If we are challenged as to why we believe that it will continue to rise as heretofore, we may appeal to the laws of motion: the earth, we shall say, is a freely rotating body, and such bodies do not cease to rotate unless something interferes from outside, and there is nothing outside to interfere with the earth between now and to-morrow.
column3: If we are challenged as to why we believe that it will continue to rise as heretofore, we may appeal to the laws of motion: the earth, we shall say, is a freely rotating body, and such bodies do not cease to rotate unless something interferes from outside, and there is nothing outside to interfere with the earth between now and to morrow.

column2: Of course it might be doubted whether we are quite certain that there is nothing outside to interfere, but this is not the interesting doubt.
column3: Of course it might be doubted whether we are quite certain that there is nothing outside to interfere, but this is not the interesting doubt.

column2: The interesting doubt is as to whether the laws of motion will remain in operation until to-morrow.
column3: The interesting doubt is as to whether the laws of motion will remain in operation until to morrow.

column2: If this doubt is raised, we find ourselves in the same position as when the doubt about the sunrise was first raised.
column3: If this doubt is raised, we find ourselves in the same position as when the doubt about the sunrise was first raised.

column2: The _only_ reason for believing that the laws of motion will remain in operation is that they have operated hitherto, so far as our knowledge of the past enables us to judge.
column3: The underscore only underscore reason for believing that the laws of motion will remain in operation is that they have operated hitherto, so far as our knowledge of the past enables us to judge.

column2: It is true that we have a greater body of evidence from the past in favour of the laws of motion than we have in favour of the sunrise, because the sunrise is merely a particular case of fulfilment of the laws of motion, and there are countless other particular cases.
column3: It is true that we have a greater body of evidence from the past in favour of the laws of motion than we have in favour of the sunrise, because the sunrise is merely a particular case of fulfilment of the laws of motion, and there are countless other particular cases.

column2: Now in dealing with this question we must, to begin with, make an important distinction, without which we should soon become involved in hopeless confusions.

column3: Food that has a certain appearance generally has a certain taste, and it is a severe shock to our expectations when the familiar appearance is found to be associated with an unusual taste.

column2: The problem we have to discuss is whether there is any reason for believing in what is called 'the uniformity of nature'.

column2: The belief in the uniformity of nature is the belief that everything that has happened or will happen is an instance of some general law to which there are no exceptions.

column2: It has been argued that we have reason to know that the future will resemble the past, because what was the future has constantly become the past, and has always been found to resemble the past, so that we really have experience of the future, namely of times which were formerly future, which we may call past futures.

column2: The question we really have to ask is: 'When two things have been found to be often associated, and no instance is known of the one occurring without the other, does the occurrence of one of the two, in a fresh instance, give any good ground for expecting the other?' On our answer to this question must depend the validity of the whole of our expectations as to the future, the whole of the results obtained by induction, and in fact practically all the beliefs upon which our daily life is based.

column2: The principle we are examining may be called the _principle of induction_, and its two parts may be stated as follows:
column3: The principle we are examining may be called the underscore principle of induction underscore, and its two parts may be stated as follows:

column2: (a) When a thing of a certain sort A has been found to be associated with a thing of a certain other sort B, and has never been found dissociated from a thing of the sort B, the greater the number of cases in which A and B have been associated, the greater is the probability that they will be associated in a fresh case in which one of them is known to be present;
column3: (a) When a thing of a certain sort A has been found to be associated with a thing of a certain other sort B, and has never been found dissociated from a thing of the sort B, the greater the number of cases in which A and B have been associated, the greater is the probability that they will be associated in a fresh case in which one of them is known to be present;

column2: (b) Under the same circumstances, a sufficient number of cases of association will make the probability of a fresh association nearly a certainty, and will make it approach certainty without limit.
column3: (b) Under the same circumstances, a sufficient number of cases of association will make the probability of a fresh association nearly a certainty, and will make it approach certainty without limit.

column2: As just stated, the principle applies only to the verification of our expectation in a single fresh instance.
column3: As just stated, the principle applies only to the verification of our expectation in a single fresh instance.

column2: But we want also to know that there is a probability in favour of the general law that things of the sort A are _always_ associated with things of the sort B, provided a sufficient number of cases of association are known, and no cases of failure of association are known.
column3: But we want also to know that there is a probability in favour of the general law that things of the sort A are underscore always underscore associated with things of the sort B, provided a sufficient number of cases of association are known, and no cases of failure of association are known.

column2: The probability of the general law is obviously less than the probability of the particular case, since if the general law is true, the particular case must also be true, whereas the particular case may be true without the general law being true. column3: We may therefore repeat the two parts of our principle as regards the general law, thus:

column2: (a) The greater the number of cases in which a thing of the sort A has been found associated with a thing of the sort B, the more probable it is (if no cases of failure of association are known) that A is always associated with B;

column2: Experience might conceivably confirm the inductive principle as regards the cases that have been already examined; but as regards unexamined cases, it is the inductive principle alone that can justify any inference from what has been examined to what has not been examined.
